reviews.text: Nice little museum with interesting, well curated exhibits.
Has lovely café to visit
GOOD
Great show, but it changes, so is better to take some information in advance on what is going on there.
Good enough for an hour break.
Not much to see but a cool place
Small place does it worth it !!!!
Nice
Great architecture. There are some associate structures around, however, the direction sign is not that clear.
Interesting to see such an old structure and so different from other Buddhist temples in the country.

90% of everything is translated into multiple languages (including English). I've lived in Korea for a long time and didn't know how much i didn't know about how everything came to be. Very informative and enjoyable museum of Korean history.
Really good museum with a lot of information provided in different ways, to see, to read and to watch (animation videos) and it's an impressive site to walk around as well.

Gyeongju is an "open museum," but the National Museum has many treasures that have been recovered from the Silla Dynasty's almost 1000 year existence. Unbelievably, the museum is open to the public at no charge!
Very interesting. Been on 2 occasions. They maintain exhibitions well and change them frequently too. Entrance was free both times!
Great historic experience for Silla, one of the strongest ancient dynasty. And shockingly it is free to all.
Don't waste your time there
The temple stay is well done here. An awesome place to learn about Korean culture and Buddhism.
This temple offers great templestay experience, also suitable for foreigners!

I recommend to go there for a morning “yoga” with monks in this temple craved in the cave on the top of the mountain. It is a good wake-up exercise for stretching our tired bodies. We had a chance to practice Seonmundo zen martial art. It is a training method taught at Golgulsa Temple designed to extinguish worldly pains and attain enlightenment. It represents mind and body control at the same time united with breathing.
Also lunch with monks was special in a spirit of well-followed rule “there must be no food left” and surprisingly high-tech feature in the temple – free wifi internet. The original temple was built out of solid rock. The head monk had gone to India to learn about Buddhism and upon his return built Gulgulsa temple which is the oldest one in Korea.
포항에서 감포가는쬑에 있는데 세계 선무도 본관이 있네요.경치도 좋아요

소박하지만 운치있다.
눈에 띄는 큰 나무들은 없지만 아름다운 나무들이 기다리고 있다.

역사가 있고 고풍적임
산책하기 좋고 조용하고 한적함

인상 깊은 곳이다
박물관도 관람 할 수 있다
주차장은 정비를 요한다
조경이 인상적입니다. 지세가 좋은지 좋은 기운을 받는 기분이 듭니다.
점심공양 받았는데..너무 맛나요..나물밥이 싱싱해요~^^ 추천합니다.
the greatest historic city in Korea
Very good
Beautiful autumn foliage & interesting to see excavation in progress. However, with high winds, there are a lot of dust & dirt in the air so keep sunglasses and scarf handy to cover your face.

The ruins of the ancient palace yard of Shilla dynasty which lasted for a thousand year. The dynasty saw its pinnacle in 7th and 8th century but has fallen in 10th century. Since the fall of the dynasty this palace yard was abandoned and now there stands no single pillar.
Nothing special. Just an empty field
If you want to visit a beach during your Kyungju trip, this is a good place for it. But, I recommend that you visit other nearby places together.
It's quite peaceful place.
Nothing but some restaurants around this spot.
it's so quite here, you can fully enjoy the beach while eating seafood or sashimi or playing with seawater and sands..
There is a tumb In the middle of rocks...
a good place but just one thing in here

Despite historical significance of this location, there is much investment that can be done to improve the place. There is currently a small place where the nobles used to enjoy, but beyond that there is nothing additional available. The site itself may show how the place itself once used to be. Entrance is 1,000 won, and parking is 2,000 won.
great land to visit

A small area with almost nothing special to see or do, but that's why I liked it. It was 1.000 won to get in, and you can bring your own food and have a picnic if you'd like. 
Really quiet. Really quaint.
Tradi tional village
Really nice change from the museums, relaxed feel with little information points dotted around all over the place. It's amazingly large, it just keeps growing as you climb each hill.
Definitely a worth visit place in Korea. Unlike the other built Han-ok villages for tourism purpose, this is a real village with history where people actually live.
Nice place for a short visit, not much to see or do

Unesco's pick! I couldn't see inner living place of some buildings because they really live there. But that point makes more attractive to me. I could feel real life there and they preserve the village. I love it :)
History retained for some years. Peace ful place.. need to walk a lot
Beautiful lake. There are trails you can try even during winters as it's not as cold as further north.

The pictures of the lake on the Internet doesn't really paint a complete picture of the lake. Learned from locals that the lake is only nice during certain periods of the year, particularly spring around Jan to Mar.

Skip this place in summer because not only there is not much to see or do around the lake during this period, the weather is also sweltering hot, reaching almost 40° Celsius.

There is a trail surrounding the lake that you can walk on to admire the view, but the beautiful bridge only works when the whole lake is filled. Cafes and other amenities dot the place too, while there are many big chains of hotels around. Some of the shops only open during the peak periods. 

Not as magical as what the internet portrayed during my visit here.

Hard to find parking zone even in rainy day. There are many visitors everyday.
But there is good scenic point.

It's a pity I didn't get to see what I saw in pictures on social media and the Internet. Perhaps it's the angle that people took pictures from. A lil disappointed but thankfully there was a nice cafe nearby to relax at (:
It's a good place to take a walk. If you visit here in Spring, you cannot miss the cherry blooms!

Atmosphere was wonderful especially in a cool autumn night. Food was delicious. We took the 39,000 menu and it was plenty and tasty, authentic but nothing too weird for my friends that are not used to Korean food, we were able to eat everything.

Pros: Food. Amazing, clean distinct and flavoursome. Food is unique, you won't find this fare in other places.  Setting, OMG amazing. Truly felt like Yangban, just like the dramas.
Cons: Not cheap. But I'd go again
Korean traditional(?) food cooked and served by 100% foreign employees
You should visit to try traditional Korean food if you are traveling near Gyeongju.
Used to really love this place, however their quality has gotten really poor over the last 3 years.
Really nice change from the museums, relaxed feel with little information points dotted around all over the place. It's amazingly large, it just keeps growing as you climb each hill.
Definitely a worth visit place in Korea. Unlike the other built Han-ok villages for tourism purpose, this is a real village with history where people actually live.

Fantastic site ~~
Beautiful
고즈넉하고 무엇보다 서원 정문 옆 세심대는 정말 풍경이 좋다. 여름에 많이들 찾아온다고 한다. 양동마을과 함께 유네스코 세계문화유산 지정.
경주 투어 스템프 2번 이라 가봤는데 생각보다 옆 바위와 물이 멋지더라구요. 겨울보다는 다른 계절에 다시 와보고 싶어요. 주차장이 밖에 있는데 오늘은 사람이 없어서 문앞까지 차를 가지고 가도 되더라구요 생각 없이 가봤다가 좋았네요
